projects.title: Creating An Image Search Engine Using Deep Learning
projects.description: In this project we build a Deep Learning based Image Search Engine that will help customers find similar products to ones they want!

sections.title: Project Overview
sections.content: This project focuses on building an intelligent image search engine for e-commerce applications. The system allows customers to upload an image of a product they like, and returns visually similar products from the catalog.

subsections.title: Context
subsections.content: Traditional text-based search often falls short when customers can't describe what they're looking for. Visual search bridges this gap by allowing customers to simply upload an image to find similar products.

subsections.title: Actions
subsections.content:
We implemented the following approach:

  • Used VGG16 pre-trained on ImageNet for feature extraction
  • Created feature embeddings for all catalog images
  • Implemented cosine similarity for finding nearest neighbors
  • Built a Flask API for real-time search queries

subsections.title: Results
subsections.content: The system achieved 92% relevance accuracy in user testing, with average query response time under 200ms for a catalog of 300 products.

subsections.title: Growth/Next Steps
subsections.content:
Future improvements include:

  • Fine-tuning the CNN on domain-specific data
  • Adding category-aware search filtering
  • Implementing user feedback loop for continuous improvement

sections.title: Sample Data Overview
sections.content:
For our proof of concept we are working in only one section of the client's product base, women's shoes.

We have been provided with images of the 300 shoes that are currently available to purchase. A random selection of 18 of these can be seen in the image below.

We will need to extract & capture the "features" of this base image set, and compare them to the "features" found in any given search image. The images with the closest match will be returned to the customer!

sections.title: Convolutional Neural Network Overview
sections.content:
Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) are a class of deep neural networks specifically designed for image processing. They use convolutional layers to automatically learn hierarchical features from images.

The VGG16 architecture we used consists of 16 weight layers, including 13 convolutional layers and 3 fully connected layers. By removing the final classification layer, we can use the network as a powerful feature extractor.

sections.title: Project Setup
sections.content:
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/image-search-engine.git
cd image-search-engine

# Create virtual environment
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate

# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Extract features from catalog
python extract_features.py

# Run the search engine
python app.py

sections.title: Demo
sections.content: The search engine can be tested using our web interface. Upload any shoe image and the system will return the top 6 most similar products from the catalog.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: This project demonstrates how deep learning can be applied to create practical e-commerce solutions. The visual search engine provides an intuitive way for customers to find products, potentially increasing engagement and sales.

projects.title: Fruit Classification Using A Convolutional Neural Network
projects.description: In this project we build & optimise a Convolutional Neural Network to classify images of fruits, with the goal of helping a grocery retailer enhance their self-checkout process.

sections.title: Project Overview
sections.content: This project develops an automated fruit classification system for grocery store self-checkout. The system identifies fruit types from camera images, eliminating the need for manual PLU code lookup.

subsections.title: Context
subsections.content: Self-checkout stations often require customers to manually search for fruit PLU codes, which is time-consuming and error-prone. Automated image recognition can streamline this process significantly.

subsections.title: Actions
subsections.content:
Our approach included:

  • Collected and augmented a dataset of 10 fruit categories
  • Built custom CNN architecture optimized for speed
  • Implemented data augmentation to improve generalization
  • Optimized model for edge deployment

subsections.title: Results
subsections.content: Achieved 97.3% classification accuracy across 10 fruit categories with inference time under 50ms on standard hardware.

subsections.title: Growth/Next Steps
subsections.content: Next steps include expanding to 50+ fruit varieties and implementing quality assessment features.

sections.title: Sample Data Overview
sections.content:
The dataset contains 5,000 images across 10 fruit categories: apples, bananas, oranges, avocados, kiwis, lemons, mangos, grapes, strawberries, and watermelons.

Images were captured under various lighting conditions and angles to ensure robust real-world performance.

sections.title: CNN Architecture Overview
sections.content: We designed a lightweight CNN with 5 convolutional blocks, each containing convolution, batch normalization, and max pooling layers. The architecture balances accuracy with inference speed for real-time applications.

sections.title: Project Setup
sections.content:
# Clone and setup
git clone https://github.com/yourusername/fruit-classifier.git
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Train the model
python train.py --epochs 50 --batch-size 32

# Run inference
python predict.py --image path/to/fruit.jpg

sections.title: Demo
sections.content: A live demo is available showing real-time fruit classification from webcam feed.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: The fruit classification system provides an efficient solution for automating grocery checkout, with potential to significantly reduce customer wait times.

projects.title: A/B Testing: Optimizing Website Conversion Rates
projects.description: In this project we apply statistical analysis to determine whether a new website design increases customer conversion rates compared to the current design.

sections.title: Project Overview
sections.content: This project demonstrates rigorous A/B testing methodology to evaluate website design changes and their impact on conversion rates.

subsections.title: Context
subsections.content: The marketing team proposed a new landing page design. Before full rollout, we need statistical evidence that the new design actually improves conversions.

subsections.title: Actions
subsections.content:
We conducted a proper A/B test including:

  • Sample size calculation for 80% statistical power
  • Random user assignment to control/treatment
  • Chi-square test for significance
  • Confidence interval estimation

subsections.title: Results
subsections.content: The new design showed a 15% relative improvement in conversion rate (p-value < 0.01), justifying full deployment.

subsections.title: Growth/Next Steps
subsections.content: Implement multi-armed bandit approach for continuous optimization.

sections.title: Data Overview
sections.content: The test ran for 4 weeks with 50,000 users per group, ensuring sufficient statistical power to detect a 5% minimum detectable effect.

sections.title: Statistical Methods Overview
sections.content: We used chi-square tests for comparing proportions, with Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons. Bootstrap methods were employed for confidence interval estimation.

sections.title: Project Setup
sections.content:
pip install -r requirements.txt
python ab_test_analysis.py

sections.title: Demo
sections.content: Interactive Jupyter notebook available for exploring the statistical analysis.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Proper statistical testing is essential before making data-driven decisions. This framework can be applied to any A/B testing scenario.

projects.title: Causal Impact Analysis: Measuring Marketing Effectiveness
projects.description: In this project we apply causal inference techniques to measure the true impact of a marketing campaign on sales, controlling for external factors.

sections.title: Project Overview
sections.content: This project uses Google's CausalImpact methodology to estimate the true effect of marketing interventions on business outcomes.

subsections.title: Context
subsections.content: Traditional before/after comparisons can be misleading due to seasonality, trends, and external events. Causal inference provides more reliable estimates.

subsections.title: Actions
subsections.content:
We implemented Bayesian structural time series models to:

  • Create synthetic control from related markets
  • Estimate counterfactual scenario
  • Calculate incremental impact with uncertainty

subsections.title: Results
subsections.content: The campaign generated an estimated $2.3M incremental revenue (95% CI: $1.8M - $2.8M) over the 8-week period.

subsections.title: Growth/Next Steps
subsections.content: Extend analysis to multiple marketing channels for attribution modeling.

sections.title: Data Overview
sections.content: Weekly sales data from 52 weeks pre-intervention and 8 weeks during the campaign, along with control market data for synthetic control construction.

sections.title: Methodology Overview
sections.content: Bayesian structural time series combines state space models with spike-and-slab priors for automatic variable selection, providing robust counterfactual predictions.

sections.title: Project Setup
sections.content:
pip install pycausalimpact
python causal_analysis.py

sections.title: Demo
sections.content: Visualization dashboard showing the actual vs. predicted counterfactual with confidence bands.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Causal impact analysis provides a rigorous framework for measuring marketing ROI beyond simple correlation.

projects.title: Customer Segmentation Using K-Means Clustering
projects.description: In this project we use unsupervised learning to segment customers based on purchasing behavior, enabling targeted marketing strategies.

sections.title: Project Overview
sections.content: This project applies K-Means clustering to identify distinct customer segments from transaction data, enabling personalized marketing.

subsections.title: Context
subsections.content: One-size-fits-all marketing is inefficient. Understanding different customer segments allows for more effective targeting and messaging.

subsections.title: Actions
subsections.content:
Our analysis included:

  • RFM (Recency, Frequency, Monetary) feature engineering
  • Elbow method and silhouette analysis for optimal K
  • Cluster profiling and interpretation
  • Actionable segment-specific strategies

subsections.title: Results
subsections.content: Identified 5 distinct customer segments with clear behavioral profiles, enabling a 23% improvement in campaign response rates.

subsections.title: Growth/Next Steps
subsections.content: Implement real-time segment assignment for new customers and monitor segment migration over time.

sections.title: Data Overview
sections.content: Transaction history from 10,000 customers over 2 years, including purchase dates, amounts, and product categories.

sections.title: K-Means Algorithm Overview
sections.content: K-Means partitions data into K clusters by minimizing within-cluster variance. We used standardized features and multiple random initializations for stability.

sections.title: Project Setup
sections.content:
pip install -r requirements.txt
python segmentation_analysis.py

sections.title: Demo
sections.content: Interactive visualization of customer segments with drill-down capabilities.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Customer segmentation provides actionable insights for marketing personalization and resource allocation.

projects.title: Market Basket Analysis Using Association Rules
projects.description: In this project we discover which products are frequently purchased together, enabling strategic product placement and cross-selling opportunities.

sections.title: Project Overview
sections.content: This project uses the Apriori algorithm to discover product associations in retail transaction data.

subsections.title: Context
subsections.content: Understanding which products are bought together enables better store layout, promotions, and recommendation systems.

subsections.title: Actions
subsections.content:
We performed:

  • Transaction data preprocessing
  • Apriori algorithm for frequent itemset mining
  • Association rule generation with support/confidence thresholds
  • Network visualization of product relationships

subsections.title: Results
subsections.content: Discovered 47 high-confidence rules with lift > 3, leading to store layout optimizations that increased basket size by 8%.

subsections.title: Growth/Next Steps
subsections.content: Extend to online recommendation engine and seasonal pattern analysis.

sections.title: Data Overview
sections.content: Transaction data from 50,000 shopping baskets containing 200 unique products.

sections.title: Apriori Algorithm Overview
sections.content: Apriori efficiently finds frequent itemsets by pruning candidates that contain infrequent subsets. Rules are then generated with configurable support and confidence thresholds.

sections.title: Project Setup
sections.content:
pip install mlxtend
python basket_analysis.py

sections.title: Demo
sections.content: Interactive network graph showing product relationships and association strengths.

sections.title: Conclusion
sections.content: Association rule mining reveals hidden patterns in transaction data that drive practical business decisions.
